title: Chemistry of some Group 18 Elements - Xe-Rn

content.question:
Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Answer the following questions about elements in Group 18 of the periodic table.

(a) Using principles of atomic structure, explain why the first ionization energy of <math alttext="R n" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mtext>n</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is less than that of <math alttext="X e" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext><mtext>e</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text:
Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Answer the following questions about elements in Group 18 of the periodic table.

(a) Using principles of atomic structure, explain why the first ionization energy of <math alttext="R n" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mtext>n</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is less than that of <math alttext="X e" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext><mtext>e</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Photoelectron spectroscopy data for the <math alttext="1 s" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> sublevel of <math alttext="X e" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext><mtext>e</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and the <math alttext="1 s" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> sublevel of <math alttext="R n" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mtext>n</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> are represented below. In terms of Coulomb’s law and atomic structure, explain why the peak for <math alttext="X e" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext><mtext>e</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is positioned so far to the right of the peak for <math alttext="R n" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext><mtext>n</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Three compounds that contain an element from Group 18 are <math alttext="X e O 2 F 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext><mtext>e</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="X e O F 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>XeO</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="X e O 3 F 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext><mtext>e</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Possible Lewis electron-dot diagrams for the compounds are shown below.

(c) Which structure, A, B or C, minimizes the formal charges for each atom in <math alttext="X e O 2 F 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext><mtext>e</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Justify your choice.

(d) A student proposes that the energy of the <math alttext="X e to O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext><mtext>e</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>to</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> bond in the structure in diagram D is less than that of the <math alttext="X e to O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext><mtext>e</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>to</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> bond in the structure in diagram E. Do you agree or disagree with the student’s claim? Justify your answer.

(e) The dipole moment of the <math alttext="X e O 2 F 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext><mtext>e</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> molecule (diagrams A, B and C) is nonzero. Identify its molecular geometry and explain how its geometry and the polarity of its bonds result in a nonzero dipole moment.

The melting point of <math alttext="X e O 2 F 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Xe</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> (diagrams A, B, C) is greater than the melting point of <math alttext="X e O 3 F 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext><mtext>e</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> (diagram E).
(f) Identify the type(s) of intermolecular force(s) that the two substances have in common.
(g) Explain the difference in melting points based on the types and relative strengths of intermolecular forces.

(h) <math alttext="X e O 2 F 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext><mtext>e</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> reacts with <math alttext="S i O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>S</mtext><mtext>i</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> to produce <math alttext="S i F 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>S</mtext><mtext>i</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="X e O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext><mtext>e</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. The unbalanced chemical equation for the reaction appears below.
<math alttext="An unbalanced chemical equation with four coefficients, labeled lowercase a through d, as follows. lowercase a , X e O 2 F 2, plus lowercase b, S i O 2, react to produce, lowercase c, S i F 4, plus lowercase d, X e O 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi><mtext> </mtext><mtext> X</mtext><mtext>e</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>b</mi><mtext> </mtext><mtext> S</mtext><mtext>i</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo>→</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>c</mi><mtext> </mtext><mtext> S</mtext><mtext>i</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext> </mtext><mi>d</mi><mtext> </mtext><mtext> X</mtext><mtext>e</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>
Give the value of each of the following coefficients in the balanced equation.
<math alttext="lowercase a equals" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="lowercase b equals" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="lowercase c equals" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="lowercase d equals" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>=</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

skill.text: 1.B: Describe the components of and quantitative information from models and representations that illustrate both particulate-level and macroscopic- level properties.
